channel.title: NPR Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Martínez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.

item.title: Former U.S. ambassador to Ukraine discusses Trump's recent criticism of Putin
item.description: What does President Trump's changing rhetoric on Vladimir Putin suggest about his relationship with the Russian leader? NPR's Michel Martin asks William Taylor, former U.S. ambassador to Ukraine.

item.title: President Trump expressing growing frustration with Russia's Vladimir Putin
item.description: For several days now, President Trump has expressed growing frustration with Russian President Vladimir Putin over the slow progress towards ending the war in Ukraine.

item.title: Hungary inspires U.S. conservatives. Its leader is seen as running a 'dictatorship'
item.description: Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán has been called "Trump before there was a Trump." Here's why his reshaping of Hungary's political institutions inspires U.S. conservatives.

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: Federal trade court blocks many of Trump's tariffs, Trump expressing frustration with Putin and Russia's continued war on Ukraine, Conservative Political Action Conference begins in Hungary.

item.title: Energy Secretary Chris Wright argues climate change isn't a crisis
item.description: Energy Secretary Chris Wright is a former oil and gas executive who argues climate change isn't a crisis. Now he runs an agency that's responsible for developing alternative energy sources.

item.title: Nepal holds first-ever monkey census to understand scope of primate-related problems
item.description: For years, people across Nepal have complained of monkeys stealing food from their properties. Now, the government is holding its first-ever monkey census to understand exactly how bad the problem is.

item.title: CPAC chair plans more conservative gatherings around the world
item.description: Conservative Political Action Conference chairman Matt Schlapp tells NPR's Leila Fadel in the Hungarian capital Budapest that the group is expanding to cities around the globe.

item.title: Why football coaches are often among the highest paid at U.S. colleges
item.description: At colleges across the U.S., football coaches are often among the highest paid people. NPR's Planet Money looks into what makes them so valuable.

item.title: Many young Hungarians looking to leave as democratic institutions decay under Orbán
item.description: Many Hungarians say they're watching their democratic institutions crumble under Prime Minister Viktor Orbán. That's now a driving factor for many young Hungarians pursuing a higher education abroad.

item.title: Trump administration pushing for national school voucher plan
item.description: The Trump administration is pushing for a national school voucher plan, which is part of the budget bill now before the Senate. But research on the success of voucher programs is mixed.
